text:
created a function with these metrics for my backtests, some more important than others

```def compute_metrics(df):
    profits = df["profit"].sum()
    roi = profits / df["size_matched"].sum()
    win_rate = df["win"].sum() / df["win"].count()
    avg_odds = df["average_price_matched"].mean()
    avg_odds_win = df[df["win"] == 1]["average_price_matched"].mean()
    avg_odds_loss = df[df["win"] == 0]["average_price_matched"].mean()
    payout_ratio = avg_odds_win / avg_odds_loss
    avg_return = df["profit"].mean()
    max_drawdown = (df["wealth"].cummax() - df["wealth"]).max()
    amount_bets = df.shape[0]
    std_dev = df["profit"].std()
    # daily returns and bet amount, mean, and std for sharpe
    df_daily = df.groupby(df["date_time_placed"].dt.date).agg({"profit": "sum", "size_matched": "sum"})
    df_daily["return"] = df_daily["profit"] / df_daily["size_matched"]
    sharpe_ratio = np.sqrt(365) * (df_daily["return"].mean() - 0.05) / df_daily["return"].std()
    
    metrics = {
        "Profits": profits,
        "Amount of Bets": amount_bets,
        "ROI": roi,
        "Win Rate": win_rate,
        "Average Odds": avg_odds,
        "Average Winning Odds": avg_odds_win,
        "Average Losing Odds": avg_odds_loss,
        "Payout Ratio": payout_ratio,
        "Average Return": avg_return,
        "Max Drawdown": max_drawdown,
        "Standard Deviation": std_dev,
        "Sharpe Ratio": sharpe_ratio
    }
    
    for metric, value in metrics.items():
        print(f"{metric}: {value}")```

elements.text: created a function with these metrics for my backtests, some more important than others

def compute_metrics(df):
    profits = df["profit"].sum()
    roi = profits / df["size_matched"].sum()
    win_rate = df["win"].sum() / df["win"].count()
    avg_odds = df["average_price_matched"].mean()
    avg_odds_win = df[df["win"] == 1]["average_price_matched"].mean()
    avg_odds_loss = df[df["win"] == 0]["average_price_matched"].mean()
    payout_ratio = avg_odds_win / avg_odds_loss
    avg_return = df["profit"].mean()
    max_drawdown = (df["wealth"].cummax() - df["wealth"]).max()
    amount_bets = df.shape[0]
    std_dev = df["profit"].std()
    # daily returns and bet amount, mean, and std for sharpe
    df_daily = df.groupby(df["date_time_placed"].dt.date).agg({"profit": "sum", "size_matched": "sum"})
    df_daily["return"] = df_daily["profit"] / df_daily["size_matched"]
    sharpe_ratio = np.sqrt(365) * (df_daily["return"].mean() - 0.05) / df_daily["return"].std()
    
    metrics = {
        "Profits": profits,
        "Amount of Bets": amount_bets,
        "ROI": roi,
        "Win Rate": win_rate,
        "Average Odds": avg_odds,
        "Average Winning Odds": avg_odds_win,
        "Average Losing Odds": avg_odds_loss,
        "Payout Ratio": payout_ratio,
        "Average Return": avg_return,
        "Max Drawdown": max_drawdown,
        "Standard Deviation": std_dev,
        "Sharpe Ratio": sharpe_ratio
    }
    
    for metric, value in metrics.items():
        print(f"{metric}: {value}")

text:
Yep been grouping my bets into EV buckets and then plotting them on a normal dist chart. Aiming to shift the mean to the right of zero and tighten it up.

There’s probably a better way of visualising that(?), but that’s what I’ve currently been attempting.

text:
The return is the return as a percentage of your account. Your "size matched" can be a large multiple of your account balance if you are actively trading in and out.
Also, the 5% represents the risk free rate, which may be may not be relevant here.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

text: If you want to test whether or not your profits are significantly different from zero, you could try resampling them a few thousand times, and plotting the distribution of the sums of each resample. that should look like a  bell curve. And if 99% of those are above zero then perhaps you have edge.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc
